Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Information Theory and Statistical Inference from Large-Alphabet Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Statistical analysis is key to many challenging applications such as text classification, speech recognition, and DNA analysis. However, often the amount of data available is comparable or even smaller than the set of symbols (alphabet) constituting the data. Unfortunately, not much is known about optimal inference in this so-called large-alphabet domain. Recently, several promising approaches have been developed by different scientific communities, including Bayesian nonparametrics in statistics and machine learning, universal compression in information theory, and the theory of graph limits in mathematics and computer science.

The investigators study the problem drawing from these multiple perspectives, but with a particular focus on developing the information theoretic approach. The research studies analytical properties of the "pattern maximum likelihood'' estimator, which performs well in practice but is not understood theoretically, and also explores computational speedups. Moreover, it attempts to delineate which problem classes are better handled by Bayesian nonparametric techniques and which by the pattern approach, and explores links between these approaches. The investigators use the resulting theory for automatic document classification, allowing for more automation in storing, retrieving, and analyzing data. Furthermore, the investigators use the theory to study genetic variations, whose link with disease diagnosis is a crucial step in the systematic quantification of biology that is playing an increasingly important role in medical advancement. The research also brings new courses to the classroom, with a special outreach effort to involve women and under-represented minorities, including through the Native Hawaiian Science and Engineering Mentorship Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project developed new tools that contribute to information theory and statistical inference in the setting of large alphabets, which have numerous applications ranging from engineering to biology. On the one hand, the project quantified the performance of certain codes for compression of data from large, unstructured alphabets, motivated by ideas from the field of Bayesian nonparametric statistics. On the other hand, the project developed new information-theoretic inequalities for large, structured alphabets such as algebraic groups. The results from the project have found applications to the fundamental limits of communication across interference channels, the design of polar codes, control theory, distributed simulation, and secure communications. Furthermore, the project has built bridges between information theory and several core areas of mathematics including additive combinatorics, harmonic analysis, probability theory, and convex geometry, making contributions to these latter areas as well as setting the stage for further fertile interdisciplinary research.

The project’s broader impact derives both from the relevance of the obtained results to applications in statistics, communication, and signal processing, and from its contribution to the development of human resources. Two doctoral students and a postdoctoral researcher were directly supported by the project and are now part of the American STEM workforce. Numerous education and training activities for graduate students were undertaken including 4 short courses on cutting-edge topics given by the PI. The PI was also involved in research mentorship of two additional graduate students and two undergraduate students, as well as in a Math Circle event for high school students in Delaware.
